turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Your honor, I'd like to ask what this model of stability and respectability has ever succeeded at?  Mrs. Kramer, were you a failure at the longest, most important personal relationship in your life?

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Objection, your honor.  The answer is, to be generous, very vague.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Can you recall any particular incident that relates to Mr. Kramer's care of his child?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: No further questions.  Thank you Mrs. Phillips.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: No questions.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: So do I.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Objection, your honor!  Counsel is harassing the witness.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Your honor, I'm only examining the man's employment record.  He pretends to fitness when he cannot hold a job.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Objection!  Your honor, counsel is raising a question that is not germane to these proceedings.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: While the child was in the care of the witness, he cut his face badly and is now scarred.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Now then, Mr. O'Connor, how long did Ted Kramer work for you?

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Eight, almost nine years.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: And did you have a close personal relationship?

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: And how did you find his work?

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: It was good.  He was a hard worker, a lot of drive, a real hustler.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: And yet you fired him.

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Ted was a good worker.  But, ah... ... after his wife left him and he was taking care of the kid on his own, things started to change. Look, I know he had problems, I understand that.  I've got problems, everybody's got problems.  But I've got a shop to run, I can't let that kind of thing get in the way...  I guess I felt that Ted was letting his duties at home interfere with his responsibilities in the office.

turns.speaker: GRESSEN
turns.text: Thank you.  I have no further questions.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Ummm, hmmm... umm, hmmm...  Well, this looks very good.. Of course  ... you understand this is the worst time of the year to look for a job.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What?!  What do you mean, I don't understand.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Mr. Kramer, nobody even thinks about leaving their job until after they get their Christmas bonus.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look, you don't understand.  I need a job.  I've got a kid and--

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: I understand and I'm absolutely sure something wonderful will turn up....  ...after the first of the year.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: There might be something at J. Walter Thompson.  But...  ...I don't think they're really serious.  The position's been open for two months and...  They may just be on a fishing expedition.  I'm sure you'll be much happier if you wait until after the first--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Call up the people at J. Walter Thompson.  Set up an appointment at four.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: Mis-ter Kramer, it's...  ...almost four now.  It's the Friday before Christmas.  Nobody is going to want to--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Either you call and set up the appointment, or I'll call.  And if I call, you lose the commission.

turns.speaker: INTERVIEWER
turns.text: My, we are a hot shot aren't we?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Now then, Mrs. Kramer, you said you were married seven years. Is that correct?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: In all that time did your husband ever strike you or abuse you physically in any way.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Did your husband strike or physically abuse his child in any way?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Would you describe your husband as an alcoholic?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: A heavy drinker?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Was he unfaithful?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Did he ever fail to provide for you?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Well, I can certainly understand why you left him.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I don't recall.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: How many lovers have you had-- permanently?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I don't recall.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: More than three, less than thirty- three--permanently?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Somewhere in between.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Do you have a lover now?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Is that...permanent?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I...I don't know...

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Then, we don't really know, do we, when you say "permanently" if you're planning to remain in New York, or even to keep the child for that matter, since you've never really done anything in your life that was continuing, stable, that could be regarded as permanent.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Whom you've seen twice in a year? Mrs. Kramer, your ex-husband, wasn't he the longest personal relationship in your life?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I suppose...

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Would you speak up, Mrs. Kramer? I couldn't hear you.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: How long was that?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: We were married two years before the baby.  And then four very difficult years.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: So, you were a failure at the longest, most important relationship in your life.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I was not a failure.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Oh?  What do you call it then --a success?  The marriage ended in divorce.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I consider it less my failure than his.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Congratulations, Mrs. Kramer. You have just rewritten matrimonial law.  You were both divorced, Mrs. Kramer.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Were you?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I thought you might just like to know that at five-fifteen this afternoon we were officially handed the Fire and Ice account by Revlon.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted, I'm leaving you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That represents a gross billing in excess of two million--  What?!

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: My American Express...My Bloomingdale's Credit Card... My check book--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Okay, okay...What is it this time? What did I do now?...

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I took two thousand out of the savings account.  That was what I had in the bank when we got married.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Joanna, whatever it is, believe me, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Here are the slips for the laundry and the cleaning.  They'll be ready on Saturday.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Now listen, before you do something you'll really regret you'd better stop and think--

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I've paid the rent, the Con-Ed and the phone bill, so you don't have to worry about them.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Look, it's not your fault, okay? It's me.  It's my fault--you just married the wrong person.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So we've got problems.  Everybody's got problems--that's normal--

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted, you're not listening to me. It's over, finished.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm listening, Joanna--believe me, I'm listening.  My wife is walking out on me after eight years of--

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: You just don't get it, do you?  I - am - really - and - truly - leaving - you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I heard you, Joanna.  I promise I heard you.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: No you didn't.  You didn't even ask about Billy.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What about Billy?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I'm not taking him with me.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted, I can't...I tried...I really tried but...I just can't hack it anymore...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: C'mon, Joanna, you don't mean that.  You're a terrific mother--

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I am not!  I'm a terrible mother! I'm an awful mother.  I yell at him all the time.  I have no patience.  No...No.  He's better off without me.  Ted, I've got to go...I've got to go.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Okay, I understand and I promise I won't try and stop you, but you can't just go...Look, come inside and talk...Just for a few minutes.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: NO!...Please...Please don't make me stay...I swear...If you do, sooner or later...maybe tomorrow, maybe next week...maybe a year from now...  I'll go right out the window.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Hello, Ted.  You look well.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So do you.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: How's the new job?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look at us, Joanna.  Just like any old married couple having dinner.  Who would believe it.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Yes...How's Billy?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I can't help but feel somehow... it's my fault.  I keep thinking I could've done something-- stopped it...

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: You can't tell it from a distance, Ted.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I've seen him.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You have?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: A few times.  Sometimes I sit in that coffee shop across the street and watch when you take him to school.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: He looks like a terrific kid.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: He is...  You sat in that coffee shop across from school--

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Watching my son...Ted, I've been living in New York for the past two months.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You've been living here, in the city?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted...The reason I wanted to see you...I want Billy back.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You want what?!

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I want my son.  I'm through sitting in coffee shops looking at him from across the street. I want my son.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Are you out of your mind?! You're the one that walked out on him, remember?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted, listen to me...You and I, we had a really crappy marriage--  Look, don't get so defensive, okay?  It was probably as much my fault as it was yours... Anyway when I left I was really screwed up--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Joanna, I don't give a--

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted, all my life I'd either been somebody's daughter or somebody's wife, or somebody else's mother. Then all of a sudden, I was a thirty-two-year-old, highly neurotic woman who had just walked out on her husband and child.  I went to California because that was about as far away as I could get.  Only... I guess it wasn't far enough. So I started going to a shrink.  Ted, I've had time to think. I've been through some changes. I've learned a lot about myself.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Such as?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Joanna, go be a mother.  Get married, have kids.  Don't get married, have kids.  Do whatever you want.  I don't give a damn. Just leave me out of it--and leave my baby out of it.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted, if you can't discuss this rationally--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Joanna, go fuck yourself!

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: I'm sorry...I just mentioned it in passing.  I never thought he'd use it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah, well he did, didn't he.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Please, Ted.  I never would have brought it up if I thought--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm not interested, Joanna. Goodbye.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Okay, I'm here.  Now why did you--

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted, do you love him?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Goddamnit, Joanna. What the--

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted, do you love him?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Ted, when we got married it was because I was twenty-seven years old and I thought I should get married and...when I had Billy it was because I thought I should have a baby...and I guess all I did was mess up my life and your life and--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Joanna, what the hell is--

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Please...Please don't stop me. This is the hardest thing I've ever had to do..

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: After I left...when I was in California, I began to think, what kind of mother was I that I could walk out on my own child. It got to where I couldn't tell anybody about Billy--I couldn't stand that look in their faces when I said he wasn't living with me.  Finally it seemed like the most important thing in the world to come back here and prove to Billy and to me and to the world how much I loved him...And I did ...And I won.  Only...it was just another "should."  ...Sitting in that courtroom. Hearing everything you did, everything you went through... Something happened.  I guess it doesn't matter how much I love him, or how much you love him. I guess it's like you said, the only thing that counts is what's best for Billy.  I don't know, maybe that's all love is anyway... Ted, I think Billy should stay with you...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: He's already got one mother, he doesn't need two...He's yours...  I won't fight you for him any more. He's yours...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, God...Oh, my God...

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Only can I still see him?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No more waiting in Coffee Shops ...I promise.

turns.speaker: JOANNA
turns.text: Okay...I think I'll go talk to my son now.  How do I look?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Beautiful.

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Ted, will you take it easy? Revlon's not about to drop an account that represents more than two million in gross billing receipts in a small agency like this, without making us sweat.  Now just relax, okay? Everything's gonna be fine.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't think so, Jim.  Maybe I shouldn't have--

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Hey, what's the rush?  C'mon, walk me a couple of blocks.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Jim, I've got to go.  I'm already late--

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Listen, Ted...I just want to tell you, when old man Schmidt retires next year, I've got a pretty

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Wow!

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: I mean it Ted, you're running this one.

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Jesus Christ.  That's a real blockbuster.  I always figured you guys had it made.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You want to know the real kicker?  The real kicker is, for the first time in my life-- the first time--I feel like a loser.

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Listen, don't let it get you down.  You're going to be fine.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Me?  I've never been better. I mean having my wife walk out on me after seven years of marriage agrees with me just fine.

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Look, Ted, I'm the oldest whore on the beat, okay?  Three marriages, two divorces...You're gonna be okay.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm going to be okay.  The way I see it, Joanna'll come home, it's just a matter of time.

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: She'll be back...

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: But...just in case...I mean, just on the off chance she doesn't. What are you going to do about the kid?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know, Jim.  This whole thing has happened so...Pow-- like that.

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Look, it's none of my business, so you can tell me to butt out, okay?  But if you want my advice, you'll send Billy away to stay with relatives for a while.  Just until you get yourself straightened out.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know, Jim...

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Ted, this may sound a little rough, but we've just landed the biggest account in the history of this agency, right? And now it's up to us--that's you and me --to deliver the goods.  Ted, you're my main man, and if I can't depend on you a hundred and ten percent, twenty-four hours a day, because you're worried about a kid with a runny nose--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Jim, I appreciate what you're saying.  I mean it, but I really think Joanna's coming back.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: 'Night, Jim.

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Hey, Ted.  C'mon in.  I wanna' talk to you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What the hell is this?

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Murray had some ideas about the Fire and Ice campaign and he had the art department make up a few roughs...  I think they're kind of interesting.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't.  Jim, this isn't anything like what we talked about.  It's not even close.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: All right, Jim.  You said I was running this show, right? You said no decisions without my approval, right?  Well what the hell is this? What's going on, Jim?

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Well, ah...I thought it over and I decided we're doing it Murray's way.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Jim, this is garbage.  This isn't anything like what we talked to Revlon about.  None of it. You can't--

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: That's my decision, Ted and that's final.

turns.speaker: O'CONNOR
turns.text: Disappointing.  It only pulled a fourteen share and they were hoping for a twenty-five minimum, and...ah...they're not very happy and...Well, the guys have decided they want to...ah, re-think the entire concept and...Look, I don't like having to do this, okay?... But...I mean, what I mean is...ah, I'm going to have to...ah, let you go--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Are you firing me, Jim?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hiya, Phyllis.  These are the Revlon contracts.  I thought you ought to check them out.

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yes, what?

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Yes, I'll have dinner with you.

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Kramer, I've got to go.  I've got an eight o'clock closing tomorrow down on Centre Street.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mmmmnph...I'll get you a cab...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: He wanted to know if I liked fried chicken.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Do you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Okay, Phyllis, what's up?

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Kramer...

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: O'Connor's out to get you.  He's going to take the Fire and Ice account away from you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What?!?

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: You want to know why?  I'll tell you why...  Another scotch and soda for the gentleman.  I'll tell you exactly why. Because you're not his buddy anymore.  Because he can't count on you to sit around the office every night until eight or nine and shoot the shit with him.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I can't.  I've got Billy to take care of.

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: You dope.  O'Connor doesn't give a damn about Billy.  All he wants is somebody that'll hang around with him every night so he won't have to go home.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't believe you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: How should I know?

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Murray.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So...what's so terrible about that?

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Oh, for God's sake, Kramer. You have got to be the world's most naive human being.  Murray has gone in and changed every single ad you've done on the entire Fire and Ice campaign. Every layout...Every idea...Every single thing, right down the line.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No.  No, I don't believe it. Jim O'Connor would never let anything like that happen.  He gave me my shot in this business. If it wasn't for Jim O'Connor I'd be--I don't know where I'd be. He's a wonderful man...

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Kramer, I'm sorry.  All I was trying to do was--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't want to hear another word against him.  Not another word.  He's a wonderful man ...a wonderful man...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So, naturally, you assume that since Joanna left, that would be a compelling point against her, right?

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: But it doesn't work that way. A major decision was handed down by the Appellate Court in 1969--in the case of Haskins vs. Haskins.

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Kramer--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Now in Haskins vs. Haskins the court ruled in favor of the mother, thus establishing a precedent for awarding the child to the mother even though she previously abandoned the baby.

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: Kramer...There's something I ought to tell you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: I've been offered a job in Washington with H.E.W.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: I'm going to take it.

turns.speaker: PHYLLIS
turns.text: It's a very good job--too good to pass up.  I'll be handling funding for the whole...  Look, I...  ..."like" you a lot.  And you...  ..."like" me, okay?  Maybe if it was a year from now, maybe things would be different...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: But it's not a year from now, is it?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SATURDAY FATHER
turns.text: Walk him over to Bethesda Fountain, buy him an ice.  It'll kill twenty minutes.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I've got a lot more than twenty minutes to kill.

turns.speaker: SATURDAY FATHER
turns.text: Tough...  ...I get off duty at five-thirty.  How long you been divorced?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Three months.  How can you tell?

turns.speaker: SATURDAY FATHER
turns.text: You've got that look.  My lady and I split two years ago in August and I'm an old pro at this shit.  First thing, stay away from the Children's Zoo.  It's pure hell--if I never see another chicken, I'll be happy.  I'm here, darling.  Don't worry...

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Mr. O'Connor called.  There's a meeting with the Revlon people in the board room and you're fifteen minutes late.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I know....I know.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Mr. Schmidt can't have the figures on the television buy until Monday.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No.  Uh, uh.  Tell him I asked for it Friday.  I want it Friday. Period.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Mr. Lombardo from packaging wants to meet on Friday.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Look, she walked out on her own child, right?  That's desertion, right? Mr. Shaunessy, I'm telling you it's an open and shut case.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: First, there's no such thing as an open and shut case. Especially where custody is involved.  Got it?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: That's if we win.  If we lose, you could end up having to pay your wife's court costs as well.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Good.  You've hired yourself a hell of a lawyer, Mr. Kramer.  How old is the child?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Six.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Look, Ted, I don't honestly think she would go to the trouble of suing you for custody of the child if she was planning on kidnapping him.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know, John...I mean, to be brutally honest, I'm not so sure what kind of mental shape Joanna's in right now.  Y'know she admitted she was seeing a shrink.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Jesus Christ.  Did you have to be so rough on her?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Do you want the kid or don't you?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Mr. Kramer, would you tell the court exactly why you want to retain custody of your child.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: When Joanna--  my ex-wife--when she was talking before about how unhappy she was during our marriage...Well, I guess most of what she said was probably true.  There were a lot of things I didn't understand-- a lot of things I would do different if I could.  Just like I guess there are a lot of things Joanna wishes she could change...But we can't.  Some things, once they are done, can't be undone.  Joanna says she loves Billy.  I believe she does.  So do I.  But the way it was explained to me, that's not the issue.  The only thing that's supposed to matter here is what's best for Billy...When Joanna said why shouldn't a woman have the same ambitions as a man, I suppose she's right.  But by the same token what law is it that says a woman is a better parent simply by virtue of her sex?  I guess I've had to think a lot about whatever it is that makes somebody a good parent:

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, Christ!

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: The judge went for motherhood straight down the line.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I lost him?  I lost him?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: I can't tell you how sorry I am.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, no..

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Ordered, adjudged and decreed that the petitioner be awarded custody of the minor child, effective Monday the 23rd of January.  That the respondent pay for the maintenance and support of said child, four hundred dollars each month.  That the father shall have the following rights of visitation: every other weekend, one night each week to be mutually agreed upon and one half of the child's vacation period.  That's it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What if I fight it?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: We can appeal, but I can't guarantee anything.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'll take my chances.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: It's going to cost.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Don't worry.  I'll get the money.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Mrs. Phillips, how long have you known Ted Kramer?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Six years.  Ever since Ted and Joanna moved into the building.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: How often do you see Mr. Kramer and his son?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Charley, my husband, and I are ...divorced and Kim, that's our daughter is about Billy's age and the children play together a lot.  So, I guess we see each three or four times a week.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY
turns.text: Can you describe the relationship between Mr. Kramer and his son?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: It's beautiful.  It's just beautiful. They have a beautiful relationship.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY'S VOICE
turns.text: Ted?  They've set the court date. I just heard today...It's...  January sixth.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, Christ.. .John, there's some- thing I ought to tell you.  My... ah, situation has...changed.  I lost my job.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: John?

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY'S VOICE
turns.text: Ted, I won't lie to you, we don't have a hope in hell of winning a custody hearing if you're out of work.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Good Christ, Joanna, just get the hell out of my life.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY'S VOICE
turns.text: Ted?  Are you there?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY'S VOICE
turns.text: Any prospects?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Don't worry.  I plan to have something within twenty-four hours, John.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY'S VOICE
turns.text: How the hell are you going to do that?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What?!  She wants what?!

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY'S VOICE
turns.text: She's the mother.  That means she's within her legal rights.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: John, what if she kidnaps him.

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY'S VOICE
turns.text: You ever see her talk to the walls?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, but--

turns.speaker: SHAUNESSY'S VOICE
turns.text: Then you don't have a choice. Have Billy at the Seventy- Fifth Street entrance to Central Park, Saturday at ten.

turns.speaker: SURGEON
turns.text: Your boy is very lucky, Mr. Kramer.  One inch over and it would have caught the eye.

turns.speaker: SURGEON
turns.text: But I'm going to have to take some stitches.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: How many?

turns.speaker: SURGEON
turns.text: Ten.

turns.speaker: SURGEON
turns.text: Now, I'd advise you to wait outside.  It'll be eas--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SURGEON
turns.text: Mr. Kramer, there's--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Fuck you.  He's my son.  I'm staying with him.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: All right, Thelma, you want to know what's going on?  I'll tell you what's going on.  I'll tell you exactly what's going on.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Look, Ted, all I--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I came home tonight.  We just got the Fire and Ice account at the agency.  Do you know what that means?!  Do you understand what that means?  It means that it was maybe one of the five best days in my whole life.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Ted, all I wanted to know was where--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I walk in the house and before I can say "How are you?", "Did you have a nice day?" before I can say anything.   Pow she's out the door.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: OhmyGod.  Didn't she say anything? She must've said something.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Yeah, she said it wasn't any use talking anymore.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Ted, don't be so hostile.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hostile?  Me?  Thelma, I'm not hostile.  I am anything but hostile.  But if you want to know what I am.  I'll tell you what I am. What I am is, I am hurt.  I am very hurt.  And I just want to know one thing, okay?  Just one thing ...Why?  That's all I want to know...Why?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Ted, Joanna and I used to talk a lot and...well, she told me a lot of...ah, things about the two of you.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Things? What kind of things?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: I mean...things.  Ted, Joanna's very unhappy and--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Listen, Joanna Kramer's got a goddamn good life.  She's got a husband that loves her.  She's got a terrific kid.  She's got a wonderful home--

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: What d'you know about how Joanna felt?  You went off to an office every morning and you'd come dragging home at seven or eight every night and as long as dinner was on the table you thought everything was swell.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Did it ever occur to you guys that Joanna Kramer's not the easiest person in the world to live with?!  Did it?!  For one thing she's always thirty minutes late.  You can set your watch by it--

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Two.  She is getting to be a real hermit or recluse or whatever it is you call it.  Thelma, do you know where I could be in this business if I had a wife that entertained or went out socially--

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Oh for shit's sake, Ted, you are the most selfish human being I have ever met.  No wonder she said you came first, then Billy, then, if there was anything left over, she got the scraps.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Joanna said that?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Then how come she never said anything like that to me?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Maybe she didn't feel like she should have to.  Maybe she felt like if you'd been paying any real attention to her to start with, maybe you would've noticed.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Boy, you guys are really something, y'know?  I'd like to know one thing, okay--just one little thing.  Did you tell Joanna she should leave me?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Y'know something Thelma--you are the typhoid Mary of divorce. I mean it.  Joanna and I never had any trouble until you and Charley split up.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Ted, divorce is a terrible thing. I know, I went through it. You've got to believe I did everything I could to get Joanna to stay.  But I'll tell you something. You may not want to hear it, but it took a lot of courage for Joanna to do what she just did.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'd like to know what the hell kind of courage it takes to walk out on your husband and your child?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know, Thel...This whole thing has happened so...Pow, like that.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: I mean, what are you going to do about Billy?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm gonna keep him, why?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Look, this is nothing personal, but I don't think you can do it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Thelma, I've lost my wife, I'm not losing my child.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: All right...Okay...But let's get something straight, right now. I mean, I'm sorry about what happened between you and Joanna, but it's not my problem, understand?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: I've got enough trouble raising my own kid.  I don't need another one.  Got it?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Got it.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: You're on your own, understand?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: You're sure?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm sure.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Wait a minute!  Wait a minute!

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Lenox Hill.  77th Street between Park and Lex.  The emergency number is 327-0800.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Slow down...Slow down...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You ever think about getting married again?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: No, not really...  I guess it's different if you don't have children, but...I dunno, even if Charley and I don't live together, even if we're sleeping with other people, even if Charley was to marry again...He'd still be my husband. That stuff about "Till death do you part?"  That's really true.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: How many onions does it say to use?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Three.  And add some basil.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: D'you think you and Charley'll ever get back together again?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: No.  I don't think so.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: C'mon, Thel.  So Charley had a little fling.  So what? All in all he was a pretty good husband.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Look,  I know this isn't gonna make any sense, okay?  I mean forget the logic part...But I keep thinking if Charley really loved me, he wouldn't have let me divorce him.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Thel, you ever hear from Joanna?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Not for a couple of months. The last time I heard from her she was living in San Francisco.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: California?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Uh, huh...She said she had a good job, was playing a lot of tennis.  She wanted to know all about Billy.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: She ever ask about me?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Uh, huh...Yeah...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What d'you tell her?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: I told her you're doing a

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: He's okay...Thel, can I ask you a favor?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't mean a little favor. mean a big F favor.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Thelma, if I die--

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I didn't say I'm going to die, but if I should--

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Don't say that!  I don't want to hear you say that!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Thel, listen to me.  If, on the million to one shot that I should--  That anything should happen to me.  Would you take care of Billy?

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Me?!  You want me to take care of Billy?!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I thought about it a lot and you're the only person I know that I trust with him.  I mean, if anything happened to me, he'd be okay with you.  You're a good mother.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: You heard anything yet?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Any day.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Ted.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh, huh...

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Ah, Charley and I are...Well, we're thinking about...I mean, actually we're sort of talking about maybe getting back together.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You and Charley?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Hey, that's terrific.

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Maybe.  I said maybe.  What I mean is, ah...I don't think it'll really work out, but Charley seems to want it, so...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Please go away, Thel...I...I just have to be by myself for a little while...

turns.speaker: THELMA
turns.text: Ted, I just heard...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Please, Thel...

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Huh.. .Hello?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: All right, Thelma...That's it. I've had it.  You can call your good friend Joanna Kramer and tell her enough is enough, okay?  I mean, I don't know what I did, but you can tell her she's made her point.

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Ted, what are you talking about?!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Don't play innocent with me, Thelma.  You know perfectly well what's going on.

turns.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Ted, I don't understand a word you're saying.  Where's Joanna?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Ha!  You tell me.

turns.speaker: BODYGUARD
turns.text: We must go, Holiness.

turns.speaker: TENZIN GYATSO
turns.text: A moment.

turns.speaker: BODYGUARD
turns.text: Please, come, Holiness.

turns.speaker: TENZIN GYATSO
turns.text: Yes. I am ready.

turns.speaker: TENZIN GYATSO
turns.text: All quiet?

turns.speaker: BODYGUARD
turns.text: Yes, Holiness.

turns.speaker: TENZIN GYATSO
turns.text: Where are you from?

turns.speaker: BODYGUARD
turns.text: Kham, Holiness.

turns.speaker: TENZIN GYATSO
turns.text: Your people are very brave. They are fighting the Chinese. No one can stop them. Not even me.

turns.speaker: BODYGUARD
turns.text: Khambas are wild men.

turns.speaker: TENZIN GYATSO
turns.text: I worry about them.

turns.speaker: BODYGUARD
turns.text: Do not worry, Holiness. They fight for you. They are under your protection.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Mama, my story.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Again?

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Your father had been very ill, we thought he would die, and some animals had died.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: Cow.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: You were a beautiful baby. So calm.

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: No cried?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: And that day, your father got better. He named you Lhamo. "The Protector."

turns.speaker: BOY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: I am sorry, Lhamo.

turns.speaker: TENZIN GYATSO
turns.text: It is alright, Father.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Not the way to talk to people.

turns.speaker: TENZIN GYATSO
turns.text: Can I do anything I want?

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TENZIN GYATSO
turns.text: But, I am in charge.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Are you? Of whom?
